stimulusHtml: All of the following likely influenced Ortega y Gasset’s assessment of European society in the mid-1920s EXCEPT

features.html:
“[We live in a period] which recognizes in nothing that is past any possible model or standard. . . . This grave dissociation of past and present is the most important fact of our time and the cause of the confusion characteristic of our present-day existence. We feel that we have suddenly been left alone on Earth; that the dead did not just die in appearance only, but in actual point of fact; that they can no longer help us. . . . Models, norms, standards are of no use to us. We have to solve our problems without any active collaboration with the past, ‘from scratch,’ be they problems of art, science, or politics. The European stands alone, without any living ghosts by his side.”

José Ortega y Gasset, Spanish philosopher, essay on art criticism, 1925

choicesHtml: the Latin American wars of independence
the devastation of the First World War
the rise of fascism in Italy
